passages.text: Economics - North America

President Trump fired Fed governor Lisa Cook while Cook refused to step down, leading to a high stakes legal battle. We expect headline payroll growth remained subdued at 85k in August. Historical patterns suggest the NFP number for July could be revised higher modestly. The unemployment rate likely ticked up by one- tenth to \(4.3\%\) . Core PCE inflation July came close to our expectation at \(0.273\%\) m- o- m, driven by nonmarket- based service components.

Earlier this week, President Trump announced he had fired Fed Governor Lisa Cook on the grounds of mortgage fraud allegations. Cook refused to step down and filed a lawsuit against President Trump. In addition, the lawsuit named the Federal Reserve Board and Chair Powell as co- defendants to refrain them from "effectuating President Trump's purported termination of Governor Cook."

Cook sought an emergency temporary restraining order to block Trump from firing her, but a judge at a federal district court did not rule on whether to issue an injunction after the first court hearing today. Key to monitor in the near term is if she could vote at the FOMC meetings during a legal battle.

Ultimately, the Supreme Court is likely to decide whether the "for cause" requirement under the Federal Reserve Act has been met. Note, the Supreme Court allowed President Trump to fire two agency leaders in May, but at the same time it made a distinction between the Fed and other federal agencies by stating: "The Federal Reserve is a uniquely structured, quasi- private entity that follows in the distinct historical tradition of the First and Second Banks of the United States."

The legal battle and its outcome would have an important implication for monetary policy. If the firing succeeds, the majority of Fed governors on the board would become dovish members (Bowman, Waller, Miran, and a new governor), which could impact the near- term monetary policy outlook. Also, the Fed board must approve the upcoming periodical reappointment of the regional Fed presidents by the end of February next year. If the majority of Fed governors reject to reappoint some hawkish regional Fed presidents, that would affect the entire FOMC and raise a risk of aggressive easing next year.

Politico reported that a hearing on the nomination of Stephen Miran to serve as a Fed governor before the Senate Banking Committee will likely happen next week. Markets are likely to focus on remarks from Republican senators on the Banking Committee. It's important to see whether Republicans on the Senate Banking Committee can unify behind Miran's nomination, while Trump's attempt to fire Fed governor Cook poses a serious threat to the Fed's independence. Miran has been nominated to only serve the expiring term of former Fed governor Kugler, which ends in January.

In an interview on CNBC, NY Fed president Williams stated that every meeting is a "live meeting." This suggested he was open to cutting rates at the September meeting. Williams reiterated his view that policy is "modestly restrictive." Considering his view on the real neutral rate, Williams said the Fed could reduce interest rates and still be somewhat restrictive.

Governor Waller remained dovish as he explicitly called for a 25bp rate cut at the September meeting and anticipated "additional cuts over the next three to six months." A 50bp rate cut was not his base case for the September meeting, but he said that his view
North America Economics

could change based on the August employment report. He focused on labor demand and downplayed the view that the unemployment rate is the best measure on labor markets. Interestingly, he expected "monthly job creation will be reduced by an average of about 60,000 a month" or 720k downward preliminary benchmark annual revision on 9 September, which is slightly smaller than the gap between nonfarm payrolls and QCEW employment between March and December 2024.
Waller described the stance of monetary policy as "moderately restrictive" which is consistent with Bowman's speech, but more dovish than other FOMC participants who said "modestly restrictive."

Based on the daily Treasury statement released earlier this week and our assumption for goods imports, the average effective tariff rate for July was about \(10.5\%\) , essentially the same as June (Fig. 1). It was somewhat surprising that the effective tariff rate plateaued in recent months. Front- loading of goods imports, which could be targeted by future Section 232 tariffs (e.g., semiconductors, pharmaceuticals and others) as well as a wider usage of USMCA goods exemptions, might have weighed on the effective tariff rate.
Fig. 1: The revenue-based effective tariff rate plateaued in recent months Various average effective tariff rate estimates
Source: USITC, US Treasury, Haver, Nomura

In addition, the Trump administration suspended de minimis exemptions for small value packages this week. According to the CBP, the total "declared value" of de minimis imports was \(64.6bn\) in 2024, which corresponds to \(2\%\) of goods imports reported by the Census Bureau. This number likely underestimated the "true" value of de minimis imports and the impact of de minimis tariffs will likely be larger than the CBP estimate implies. The impact of suspension of de minimis tariff exemptions seems to be heavily concentrated in e- commerce. We will likely see more tariff revenues, but slower goods spending and higher goods prices. In particular, we could see some notable price pressures on apparel prices as the share of apparel products in total e- commerce sales is high.

Employment growth remained tepid in August. We expect headline NFP grew 85k as private payrolls growth slowed to 80k, while government employment rebounded modestly following a negative print in July. Focus would be on data revisions, given the large downward revisions in the July report. Historically, July has been revised modestly higher in the second estimate, while the June print has been revised lower. Overall, we think the revisions are unlikely to change the recent trajectory of monthly NFP growth.
Lead indicators have been negative lately, pointing to subdued employment growth. Employment indices of services surveys have declined (Fig. 2), while the claims remained
elevated through the survey reference week (Fig. 3).
Fig. 2: The employment indices of regional Fed services surveys declined in August
Source: ISM, S&P Global, Regional Federal Reserve banks, Haver, Nomura

We expect the unemployment rate ticked up to \(4.3\%\) from \(4.2\%\) in July. It is likely to move up gradually, driven by slower hiring rather than layoffs. Measures of hiring have trended down. The Conference Board labor differential dropped to its lowest level since February 2021 (Fig. 4). Our forecast for July JOLTS opening suggests the V- U ratio edged down to 1.02 from 1.06 previously. Layoffs have edged up but remain near historical lows (Fig. 5). Average hourly earnings (AHE) growth likely remained sideways at \(0.3\%\) in August, boosted by a strong calendar effect in the month.
Fig. 4: The Conference Board labor differential moved down to 9.7 from 11.0, its lowest print since February 2021
Source: BLS, The Conference Board, Haver, Nomura
Fig. 3: Continuing jobless claims have edged down recently, but remained elevated over the survey reference period
Source: DOL, Haver, Nomura
Fig. 5: Layoffs have edged up but remain near historical lows Measures of job losses
Source: BLS, Haver, Nomura

Core PCE inflation remained relatively elevated at \(0.273\%\) m- o- m in July following a revised \(0.256\%\) in June (Nomura: \(0.287\%\) , Consensus: \(0.3\%\) ). Backward revisions were mixed as April and May were revised lower, while June was revised higher. The 3- month
annualized core PCE inflation rose to \(3.0\%\) from \(2.6\%\) in June and the 12- month change rate also accelerated to \(2.9\%\) (2.877%) from \(2.774\%\) in June (Fig. 6).
Fig. 6: 3-month annualized and 12-month changes in core PCE price index accelerated in July
Source: BEA, Haver, Nomura
Fig. 7: Although core PCE inflation remained elevated, core goods inflation was essentially muted in July
Source: BEA, Haver, Nomura

Although core PCE inflation remained elevated in June and July, driving factors were quite different. Core goods inflation was essentially muted in July after a \(0.4\%\) m- o- m advance in June (Fig. 7). Conversely, volatile portfolio management and investment advise service prices jumped by \(5.4\%\) m- o- m in July, making a \(+9\) bp contribution to core PCE inflation. In addition, prices for nonprofit institutions serving households (NPISH) rebounded in July. The aggregate contribution of nonmarket- based service components (including portfolio management and NPISH) to July core PCE inflation was \(+13\) bp, up from zero in June (Fig. 8). Considering policymakers often downplay the impact of volatile nonmarket- based service components, Powell might look through some strength in July core PCE inflation at the September FOMC meeting.
Fig. 8: Nonmarket-based components pushed up July core PCE inflation
Source: BEA, Haver, Nomura
Looking ahead, we expect the impact of higher tariffs to materialize further, keeping monthly core PCE inflation elevated at \(0.3\%\) m-o-m over the coming months.
Q2 real GDP growth was revised higher to \(3.3\%\) q-o-q ar. close to our expectation (Nomura: \(3.4\%\) , Consensus: \(3.1\%\) ) from its preliminary print of \(3.0\%\) (Fig. 9).

The upward revision was largely concentrated in private domestic spending. Real final sales to private domestic purchasers was revised up by \(0.7pp\) to \(1.9\%\) from \(1.2\%\) previously (Fig. 9). This is close to the median of FOMC participants' longer- run real GDP projections ( \(1.8\%\) ). In addition, GDI, an alternative measure of economic growth, surged by \(4.8\%\) . This suggested that economic activity remained resilient in Q2 from an income growth perspective.

Data released this week was positive for Q3 GDP tracking on net. Durable goods orders surprised to the upside, as core capital goods shipments remained robust in July. Despite a widening in advance goods trade deficit, some of the increase in goods imports was likely due to a surge in gold imports, which does not feed into GDP calculations (Fig. 10). Our tracking estimate for Q3 GDP is \(1.1\%\) q-o-q ar, up from \(1.0\%\) last week. Our estimate for real final sales to private domestic purchasers is \(0.7\%\) from \(0.4\%\) last week.
Fig. 9: Q2 real GDP growth was revised higher to \(3.3\%\) q-o-q ar. close to our expectation, driven by an increase in real final sales to private domestic purchasers
Note: Dashed lines denote preliminary estimate Source: BEA, Haver, Nomura
Fig. 10: Despite a widening in the advance goods trade deficit, some of the increase in goods imports was likely due to a surge in gold imports
Source: Census Bureau, BEA, FSO, FRB, Haver, Nomura
Job gains likely edged up, while the unemployment rate ticked up in August.

ISM Manufacturing (Tuesday): We expect the ISM Manufacturing Index likely ticked up to 48.7 in August from 48.0 in July. Regional Fed manufacturing surveys pointed to a modest improvement in manufacturing activity, while the preliminary print of the S&P manufacturing PMI returned to expansionary territory in the month. An extension of the trade truce with China was also likely a tailwind for sentiment.

JOLTS (Wednesday): Job openings likely fell to 7370k in July from 7437k in June. Our forecast suggests the job openings rate remained sideways at \(4.4\%\) . The V- U ratio likely ticked down to 1.02 from 1.06 previously, its lowest level since March, consistent with the recent decline in the Conference Board labor differential. Alternative data from Indeed and Lightcast suggest that total job openings have continued to edge down, despite a modest pick up in new job openings. Hiring rate likely picked up in July following a tick down in June, in line with the July employment report.

Fed Beige Book (Wednesday): Based on regional Fed business surveys since early July, business sentiment likely continued to improve gradually. The latest Beige Book said economic activity "increased slightly" and the general economic assessment in the next Beige Book could be upgraded to "increased modestly" or "moderately." It would be important to monitor comments on labor markets, in particular, the availability of foreign- born workers as well as the status of hiring and layoffs. Another key point to watch is whether higher costs from tariffs were passed on to consumers. Note that the latest Beige Book mentioned a higher likelihood of price increasing "more rapidly by late summer."

Vehicle sales (Wednesday): Vehicles sales likely grew 16.1mn saar from 16.4mn in July. An end to EV incentive in September accelerated the EV sales. Additionally, Labor Day deals and promotional incentives likely boosted sales.
Trade balance (Thursday): Advance goods trade deficit widened more than expected to 103.6bn in Jul. We expect the trade deficit widened to \(76.5bn\) in July.

Jobless claims (Thursday): Both initial and continuing claims ticked down this week. Initial claims remained low while continuing claims remained at a relatively elevated level, which is consistent with a low- hiring and low- firing situation. We expect a similar trend to continue in coming weeks.

Nonfarm productivity (Thursday): Considering the upward revision to Q2 real GDP, the final estimate of nonfarm productivity will likely be revised higher by three- tenths to \(2.7\%\) while the growth of unit labor costs will likely be revised down to \(1.2\%\) due to higher productivity growth and downward revisions to labor inputs.
ISM Services (Thursday): The ISM Services Index likely ticked up to 51.2 in August from 50.1 in July. Regional Fed services survey noted an improvement in activity and local business conditions.

Employment Report (Friday): We expect headline nonfarm payrolls (NFP) likely grew 85k in August. Historical patterns suggest payrolls could be revised higher modestly for July. Private job gains likely remained slow at 80k following a 83k increase in July. Government employment likely rebounded following a negative print in July.

We forecast the unemployment rate, which has been emphasized by policymakers as a reliable measure to gauge labor market strength, likely ticked up by one- tenth to \(4.3\%\) in August. Average hourly earnings (AHE) growth likely just rounded down to \(0.3\%\) m- o- m. Risks are skewed towards a higher print due to a positive calendar effect in August. The labor market is losing momentum, and shifting balance of risks to the Fed's dual mandate is likely to lead to a 25bp cut at the September meeting. Contained layoffs and few signs of acute labor market stress are likely to limit aggressive easing though.
Fig. 11: Forecasts for economic indicators released during the week of 1 September

Source: Haver, Bloomberg, Nomura
We expect a 25bp cut in September. Inflation risks are skewed higher, but with core PCE tracking the Fed's \(3.1\%\) ye forecast, we expect easing in line with the June dot plot.

Economic activity: Employment growth is rapidly losing momentum, consistent with broader signs of below- trend growth in 2025. Recession risks remain elevated; however, our base case is a slow but continued expansion, supported by healthy consumer balance sheets and stable financial conditions for businesses. The Trump administration announced new reciprocal tariff rates for dozens of US trading partners, which went into effect on 7 August. More sector specific tariffs are likely to be announced in the coming months. Tariffs will be a headwind to consumer spending, and heightened uncertainty over trade policy is likely to dampen business investment.

Inflation: Inflation remains well- above the Fed's \(2\%\) target, and risks are skewed to the upside, in our view. Signs of tariff- related price pressures persist in goods inflation, which we expect will intensify when automakers transition to a new model year and set new prices in the coming months. We forecast year- end core PCE of \(3.2\%\) . A worsening growth outlook should cause the inflationary impulse from tariffs to fade relatively quickly, as we expect month- on- month core inflation to moderate substantially, starting in Q4 this year.

Policy: We expect further sector- specific tariffs to be announced, including on lumber, and pharmaceuticals. The provisions of the One Big Beautiful Bill Act (OBBBA) passed by the Congress are likely to be modestly stimulative in the near term. On monetary policy, we now expect the Fed will cut rates 25bp at their September meeting. We expect this to be followed by additional quarterly cuts in December and March. Data since the June FOMC meeting have demonstrated a sharp deterioration in employment data and less inflation pressure than feared. In our view, this will likely leave the Fed on track to deliver the June dot plot median, which showed two cuts in 2025. We expect the Fed to end its balance sheet rundown (QT) in March 2026.

Risks: Trump may opt to de- escalate trade conflicts or focus on other aspects of his economic agenda. Inflation from higher tariffs could prove persistent, spilling into domestic prices or long- term inflation expectations.
Fig.12:United States:Details of the forecast

Note: The unemployment rate is a quarterly average as a percentage of the labor force. Nonfarm payrolls are average monthly changes during the period. Inflation measures and calendar year GDP are year- over- year percent changes. The GDP measures in the last column refer to Q4/Q4. The Fed securities portfolio is end- of- period. The annual interest rate forecasts are end- of- period. Housing starts are period averages. Numbers in bold are actual values. Table reflects data available as of 29 August 2025. All Nomura forecasts are modal.
Source: BEA, BLS, Census Bureau, FRB, Haver, Nomura
Fig. 13: Weekly data tracker and its decomposition

Note: We estimate a latent factor that contributes the most to the total variance of 13 daily and weekly US indicators covering industrial and consumer sectors via principal component analysis (i.e., the first principal component). We calibrate this factor to track four-quarter changes in real GDP. Source: AAR, Baker Hughes, DOL, EIA, EEI, MBA, PolicyUncertainty, Redbook Research, SF Fed, Haver Analytics, Nomura
